header.title: The New Writings of Rav Ashlag: One Precept Part 2

central_thesis: Given the widespread spiritual decline and the difficulty in traditional religious observance, the most effective and accessible path to spiritual rectification and ultimately achieving 'for its own sake' (Lishma) is to dedicate oneself primarily to the precept of serving one's fellow human beings, limiting personal needs to survival alone. This altruistic focus serves as a foundational training that purifies intent and prepares one for a deeper, genuine connection to the Creator.

structure_content.chapter_title: The issue of the precepts [regarding the relationship] between a person and his friend
structure_content.summary: The text opens by acknowledging the traditional adherence to the Sages' words but highlights a contemporary crisis: post-War societal changes have led to a decline in patience and an increase in rebelliousness, especially among the youth. This has rendered the traditional approach to studying Torah and following precepts, particularly the concept of 'not for its own sake' (Lo Lishma) for the masses, largely ineffective due to a profound loss of respect for the Torah. The traditional stepping stone of performing precepts for ulterior motives before ascending to 'for its own sake' is no longer viable for modern spiritual aspirants.

structure_content.chapter_title: A minimal approach to spiritual work
structure_content.summary: To address the spiritual malaise, the author proposes a 'minimal fashion' return to spiritual work and faith for young Israelites. Instead of demanding complete adherence to all Torah and precepts immediately, the call is to accept at least one precept. This approach is supported by the teaching of Chabbakuk, who condensed all precepts into 'A righteous person lives by his faith'. The text differentiates this minimal entry point from the severe condemnation of those who, having achieved perfection, deliberately reject even one precept, implying that the current state necessitates a different starting strategy.

structure_content.chapter_title: The safer choice: Service to others
structure_content.summary: The core proposition for achieving 'for its own sake' is presented: before one reaches perfect intention, the impact of partial versus total fulfillment of precepts is not critical. The safest and most direct precept to cultivate 'Lishma' is to drastically minimize personal needs to bare survival, dedicating all remaining time and effort to public service. This includes aiding the distressed, the sick, and any creature in need, emphasizing altruistic action as the primary spiritual work.

structure_content.chapter_title: Serving people according to the precepts of the Creator: Two virtues
structure_content.summary: The precept of serving others possesses two key virtues. Firstly, it is universally understandable and globally accepted, making it accessible and appealing to young individuals. Secondly, and more profoundly, this specific precept is deemed a superior vehicle for ultimately internalizing and performing the Torah and all precepts 'for its own sake'. It is argued that such altruistic work, done for the benefit of others rather than self-love, is a more effective preparatory stage than performing all 613 precepts motivated by self-interest. Through this practice, one gradually shifts their intention to truly serve the Creator, which is the ultimate goal.

key_concepts.definition: Divine commandments or spiritual practices derived from the Torah. In this context, they are seen as avenues for spiritual development and connection to the Creator. The text differentiates between general precepts and 'bein adam lechavero' (between a person and his friend) precepts.

The highest form of spiritual intention, wherein one performs precepts or spiritual work purely for the sake of the Creator, devoid of any personal gain, reward, or self-interest. It signifies altruistic devotion and is the ultimate goal of spiritual practice in Kabbalah.

key_concepts.term: Not for its own sake (Lo Lishma)
key_concepts.definition: Performing precepts or spiritual work with an ulterior motive, such as fear of punishment, desire for reward, or personal benefit. While traditionally seen as a valid, initial stepping stone to Lishma, the text argues it's become ineffective for the modern spiritual climate.

key_concepts.term: Relationship between a person and his friend (Bein Adam Lechavero)
key_concepts.definition: Interpersonal precepts focusing on altruism, compassion, mutual aid, and social responsibility. The author posits this category of precepts as the most vital and accessible starting point for contemporary spiritual aspirants to cultivate 'Lishma'.

The dedicated effort, practice, and discipline involved in spiritual growth and adherence to divine will. The text redefines the initial focus of 'Avodah' towards altruistic action rather than purely ritualistic or self-focused study.

Trust and belief in God, underscored as a foundational element of a righteous life, echoing Chabbakuk's teaching. It is presented as a crucial component even in the 'minimal fashion' of spiritual return.

practical_system.description: The 'practical system' outlined is an operative method for achieving the Kabbalistic ideal of 'Lishma' (acting for its own sake) by initially bypassing the complexity of full Torah observance and focusing on a singular, universally understood ethical precept. This system posits that by consciously and rigorously limiting one's personal material needs to the bare minimum required for survival, and then dedicating all surplus time, energy, and resources to the selfless service of others (the depressed, ill, or anyone in need), one systematically purifies their intention. This altruistic action, being inherently 'not for its own sake' in a self-serving manner, gradually retrains the practitioner's inner being, shifting their motivation from ego-centric desire to genuine other-centeredness. This process is understood as a preparatory 'work' that naturally and organically cultivates the pure intention necessary to truly fulfill all precepts 'for the sake of the Creator', thereby facilitating a deeper and more authentic spiritual connection.
tools: Universal ethical understanding (as a common ground for practice)
The precepts of 'between a person and his friend' as guiding principles
rituals: Limiting personal consumption to minimal survival needs
Actively engaging in public service for the benefit of others (the depressed, ill, or any creature in need)

relevant_quotes.text: The issue of the precepts [regarding the relationship] between a person and his friend
And yet, after the outbreak of the War, people's patience has become weak and especially the young lost the power to control themselves and have become completely rebellious.
[even] the whole issue of “not for its own sake", which the [spiritual] work of the masses is based on, is completely not the custom in these days because respect for the Torah has completely fallen.
Therefore I have come out with this call to the young Israelites to return to the [spiritual] work [that was given] by God and to the faith in Him in a minimal fashion.
Because we do not require of them immediate total acceptance of the Torah and the precepts, but that each and every one would at any rate accept one precept.
As the Sages have said: "Chabbakuk came and summed them all in one: A righteous person lives by his faith."

And therefore I say that the first and only precept that would be a safer choice for one who wishes to achieve "for its own sake” is not to take the work upon himself except for the minimum requirements to live; That is, to say exactly to the point of only providing one's own survival. And the rest of the time one should be working for the public, to help the depressed and the ill, and every creature in the world that needs rescue or simply some benefit.

Serving people according to the precepts of the Creator: This precept has two virtues: one is that every young person will understand what he is doing, because this work is agreed upon and approved by people from all over the world; and the second is that it is possible that this precept is a better instrument to bring us to keep the Torah and the precepts for its own sake, than performing all the 613 precepts if they are done because of self love.
Ultimately, of course, the motivation should be to fulfill the precepts of the Creator.

critical_analysis.relevance: This work by Rav Ashlag, as presented by Meir Yeshurun, offers a highly relevant and radical reinterpretation of initial spiritual practice within Kabbalah, specifically designed for a post-traditional, spiritually challenged era. It shifts the focus from rigid adherence to all 613 Mitzvot or even the traditional 'Lo Lishma' as an entry point, towards an accessible and universally laudable ethical foundation. For the contemporary esoteric practitioner, particularly within Western Esotericism that often grapples with fragmented traditions and individualistic paths, this text provides a powerful framework for ethical integration into spiritual work. It posits altruism not merely as a moral good, but as a potent, operative method to purify intention and activate genuine spiritual connection, making it a 'better instrument' than purely self-serving ritual, a concept deeply resonant in various magical traditions emphasizing ethical purity for effective operation.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience is 'young Israelites' who have become disconnected from traditional Torah study and precept observance due to modern societal challenges and a general decline in spiritual respect. However, given the universal nature of its ethical prescription and its practical approach to cultivating pure intention, it extends to anyone within the broader esoteric and occult community seeking a foundational ethical system to support their magical or spiritual development. It speaks to individuals who may feel overwhelmed by complex magical systems or seek to integrate altruistic service as a core component of their personal 'work'.
